div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Services fortnightly from HAMBURG weekly from ANTWERP; every 4 weeks from BORDEAUX direct to Alexandria; homewards every 2 weeks from ALEXANDRIA for ROTTTERDAM and HAMBURG. Goods forwarded at through-rates from all German Railway on direct Bills of Lading to ALEXANDRIA, CAIBO, SYRIA, etc. Special facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc. from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German manufacturing towns.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon ; Every Monday at 6 p.m, steamer leaves Sue for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate streamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah lat call at Tor, (for Sinai), El Wedji and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.

Steamer leaves Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. arrive Brindisi at 5 a.m Trieste Tuesday 5 a.m

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Happy Christmas to all our readers.

div.head: Dynamite Explosion
div.p: Yesterday a native was killed by an ex­plosion of dynamite at Mei

div.head: The National University
div.p: The total amount of the subscription* to the National University is now L.E. 18 136.
This German training ship is leaving Alexandria on Thursday next for Beyront. There are five young Turkish cadets on board.

div.head: Ghezireh Palace
div.p: The email dances at Ghezireh Palace Hotel will be resumed on Thursday next and will be continued every Thursday doting the season.

div.head: A Bedouin Raid
div.p: The Egyptian Government has drawn the attention of the Governor General of Barbary to the mid by Benghazi Bedouin in the village of Salom where they seized 150 camels.

div.head: St. Andrew's Church, Cairo
div.p: There will be a special musical service in this chord) at 10 40am. on Christmas Day and again at the earns hour ow New Year's Dey On Sunday, the 30th inst., there will be Communion service at 10:30 a.m. and 6 pm.

div.head: ABYSSINIA TO THE NILE.
div.p: Cairo Kuttabe.

The Ministry of Public Instruction has asked the Wakfs Administration to add L B. 1,500 to the amount formerly appointed for improving the Cairo Kattab The total will accordingly amount next year to LB 18,000.
SITUATION IN MOROCCO.
AN ARMY IN RAGS
CHEREFIAN TROOPS OUTSIDE TANGIER
Paris, December 22.
M. Pichon has announced to the Council of Ministers an improvement in the situation on the Algero Moroocan frontier.
Tangier December 23

Guebbaa Army ia now enoamped outside the city. His men are mostly in rage. The local Governor borrowed the liveries of servants of European residents to give a respectable appearance to his few troops when he went out to meet Guebbas.
There is a strong feeling amongst Europeans thatt Guebbaa’ troops would be more likely to attack Europeans than El Raiaoli’a men.
Later.
The Governor of the city went ont to meet Guebba's troops. El Raisilis followers are holding aloof.

Telegrams from Spanish sources state the Mooriah Pretender was victorious in the re ent fighting against the Kabyled, and is seeking the support of the Riffs for an attack on the Imperial army. (Reuter)
Paris, December 23.
It is reported from Tangier that the War Minister Guebbas has arrived there at the head of the Chereefian troops. (Harvas)
FRENCH SEPARATION LAW
CONCILIATORY MODIFICATIONS.
Paris, December 22.

The Chamber, by 418 votes to 166. passed the new Government Bill modifying the separation law in a manner concilatory to the Church, despite the opposition of the Radical Socialiats, whose attitude has lately been causing apprehension of a Ministerial defeat
In the course of the debate on the navy M Thomson stated that half of the new warships would be fitted with turbines. (Reuter)

div.note:
Teheran, December 22.
The Shah’s health is very unsatisfactory The Crown Prince has been appointed Regent, (Reuter)
Teheran December 23.
At 4 o'clock this afternoon the Shah waa sinking rapidly. (Reuter)

GOVERNOR OF THE TRANSVAAL.
LORD BELBURNE’S APPOINTMENT.
London, December 22. The ’‘Gazette” announces that Lord Sei borne has been appointed Governor of the Transvaal. (Reuter

div.p: RUSSIA AND JAPAN.
MR BALFOUR AND THE
EDUCATION DISPUTE
London, December’22,
The action of Mr. Balfour with regard to the Education dispute is criticised in certain Con­servative circles He is charged with subordii at- ing policy to mere tactics. (Reuter)
DUKE OF CONNAUGHT’S TOUR.
London, December 23.
It is officially stated that the Duke of Connaught will start on bis tour on 10th January. (Reuter)
QUEEN VICTORIA’S ACCOUCHE
MENT
Madrid, December 22.
The Gazette” announces that the Queen’s accouchement is expected in April. (Rmi r)
UNIVERSAL SUFFRAGE IN
AUSTRIA.
Viknna, Deoember 22.
Both HodM' have piRned universal anffraga in order, as tie Premier said, to secure peaoa in Austria. (Reuter
SPRINGBOKS DEFEAT CORNWALL
London, Deoember 22.
Football. Rugby. The South Africans de leafed Cornwall by 2 points to 3. (Reuter)
TELEGRAMS.
RUSSIAN OUTRAGE.
rol'NT IGNATIEFF SHOT DEAD
St. Petersburg, December 22.
Count Alexia Ignatieff, the former Governor General of Kief, has been assassinated at Tver by an unknown person, who tired six revolver shots The Count’s asaassin has been arre-ted (Reuter)
Tver, Deoember 2?.
Count Alexis Ignatieff was shot dead to dsy at the buffet of the Club of the Nobility. The murderer attempted suicide, but only managed to wound himself. Rtvtat)
GERMAN ELECTIONS
NEW REICHSTAG’S FIRST TASK.
Berlin, Deoember 22

The Government, through the medium of semi-official journals, has submitted its pro­gramme of elections. It traits that the nation will render a second diroolution unnecessary, and says that no new Kolturkampf ia contem­plated.
The Conservative organ ‘ Rsichsbote ' de­ciares that the first task of ths new Rsichatag will be a vigorous naval programme. (Reuter)
DUMA ELECTIONS.
St. Petersburg. Deoember 22.
The elections for the Duma have been fixed for the 19th February. (Reuter)
VIENNA POSTAL EMPLOYES.
Vienna, Deoember 22.
The postal employ^ have resumed work.
CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
REPORT OF THE DIRECTORS

Tne directors consider the results attained in the year ended September 30 as evidenoirg the high intrinsic and economic value of the rights possessed by the corporation. '1 he operations reviewed have not been of an ex peditionary nature Tbe definite ascertain­ment of the permanency and excellency of tbe water supply dispelled any doubts that may have existed respecting it, and clearly revealed the land as the constitutive factor in deter mining the prosperity of the enterprise. Land development has consequently received primary consideration. The subsidiary works are im cortant, and in tbe opinion ot the directors are capable of contributing in no small degree to tbe corporation's earning capacity, but relatively to the land they are quite subei diary. A preliminary number of bores have been pat down, and land for experimental purposes, on which cotton and numerous other crops have been most successfully grown, has been cultivated around each of the finished wells. Pending the completion of the 'ail way, which at the oLwe of tbe year under review wm completely laid to kilometre 67, the number of drilling machines has been strictly limited owing to tbe excessive cost of camel transport Mineral research has been actively prosecuted, and a large amount of analytical and exploratory work hu been carried out, while actual divelopment of proved beds of earthy minerals has bien accomplished. The directors record that tbe Egyptian Government have missed no opp^r tunity of extending their assistance to tbe cor poration in matters pertaining to the develop ment of the ones ; and they are confi lent th it tbe attitude of the G jvernmeut will continue to be of the most friendly character. Recent expren non has been given to the deteriuinati n of tbe Government to assist the corporation in its operations in every reasonable way. In order to complete the railway to Khugih as early as possible in the coming year and to oops w th the work of land reclamation on a large scale, arrangements are being male for the early issue of the balance of capital. Meantime the final call of 5s. per share, making all shares fully paid, has been made, so as to enable vigorous construction to proceed an interruptedly. Pending completion of the railway, it has not been deemed advisable to deal with the oases prodnoa on any exten lei scale, but purchases of tba supjriir dates of the oases have beau m id s f >r c msignuuot i> balk both to C»iro and L)i<i»t), ami these consignments it has baen possib a to sen I over he corpir*ti m u line so fr a< th hn u?en ■ompleted. W th th a c nn •lot,on 't th a rail way, extended and imm i lately profi able’ride ts antioipUel in th^a an 1 u many o'h r articles of produce.

DE\N Bl'Ti llEll’S RETIREMENT.
HIS OLD PARISHIONERS
The following communication has been re chived by Lord Cromer —
To His Excellency Lord Cromer, PC., G.C.M.G., &o., Ac, &c.

My Lord,—I read with extreme pleasure in tbe “PallMallGdizette”of the7th insU.that your Lordship presided at a meeting of the English and American residents in Cairo, to consider the question of presenting a testimonial to tbe Very Rev. Dean Butcher. It has occurred to me that it would, perhaps, be interesting to your Lordship and those with wh^m yon are acting, to know the opinion of the parishioners of Hammersmith on tbe departure of Mr Butcher 42 years ago after having served as Curate of the Parish Church for fi e years.

Tbe enclosed statement will appear in the Paul's Pariah Magazine for January next, and if your L?rd-hip shoo’d consider it would be of interest at the present juncture you are at liberty to communicate any portion of it t) the English press in Cairo.

As a lad of 12 years old I hive a distinct recollection of the kindly feeling entertained by all classes for Mr. Butcher, and the univer sal regret at his departure , I also remember with gratitude his kindness to my sick mother who died the year after he left.

I trust your Lordship will pardon me tor venturing to address yin, but 1 could not resist giving yon this i iformation regarding one for whom 1 have always entertained th^ highest feelings of respect and affection. — I have, etc ,
8. Martin.
Hammersmith, December 13th.
The following is the atatemeut referred to : —
DE\N BUTCHER.

Iu June, 1861, the Rev. Charles Henry Batcher, M.A., resigned tbe curacy of St Paul’n, H immersurith, to take uphi< datiei as Consular Chaplain at Shanghai. During ths fivey aro be had worked in Hammersmith he had endeared himself to the parishioners
Happily there are a few of tbe present congregation, of whom tba writer is one, who remember bis sterling worth as a minister and preacher, and who still regard him with affectionate remembrance.

It was oonfi iently anticipated that Mr. Bu' ober would make bis mark in th] Church, and his services were so highly appreciated that in 1876 he was raised to the dignity of Dean of tbe Ca’b>dral of the 11 >'y T iiity, Slnugha .

Iu 1883 he reiigne i the Deane y, and was appointed Chaplain of All Saint", Cairo, Mr Bucher also held tbe o Hi e of E. C. Arcbdeao >n ia Egypt from 1890 to 1895. Advancing years have now compelled his retirement.

[Here follows a report of the recent meeting at tbe British Agency where it was announ­ced that the testimonial would take the form of a purse of gold. The Parish Magazine’s article then procaeds as follows ]
It may be of interest to recall a similar pre­sentation as the one proposed which was male by the congregationofS . Pa il’s, Hammersmith, 42 years ago.
The testimonial consisted of an illuminate! address, a silver salver, an I a purse of £100. It
flrriiVID COIM ID

was presented m the occasion of a schorl treat held in ths grounds of an o'd house in Shepherd's Bush Road, known as' Tbe Poplars,” the site of wh'ch is now marked by Poplar Grove. The chair was taken by tbe Rev. J. Connell, Vicar, who was supported by Mr W. Smith, Churchwarden (founder of Smith's Almshouses), Dr. Moxey, Mt Wing, Mr. Jamei Hunt, Mr A. J. Riberts (late Vestry Clerk), Rev. W. L. Collett, late Vicar of St. Stephen’s, and other leading parishioners.
Tbe Vioar read the following address. Hammersmith, St. Paul’s Vestry,
Jane, 1864
To the Rev. Charles Henry Butcher, M. A. Rev and Very Dear Sir,

In response to the very general desire of tbs Congregation of St. Paul’s a Teskimoaial Subscription List was opened shortly after the abnonnoemeat of year anticipated removal. It was felt instinctively that your earnest pastoral labour-’, diligent ca-e, and unwearied anxiety for the spiritual welfare of our deutely populat­ed pariah during five years’ residence amongtt us should not pass away without special re­cognition and record. These sentiments, atreog- thenel in many by feeling] of da'p personal regard and aff lotion have found their natural expression (at th's juncture) in the eager anxiety of all classci without exception to participate in a parting evidence of goodwill and Christian sympathy. It has been judged best to leave our united freewill offering (to which the poorest have heartily contributed acoordiag to theiv ability) entirely at your dis- pAsal rather than convey it in a form (however . gratifying) which might prove cumbersome it not useless in your far-c ff home and untried position. Be assured wa express alike our own and the spontaneous universal feeling of all with whom you have been associated here when in taking leave we wish you and ye ars health and happiness, but above all that in your future sphere of duty you may expariencj personally and be made to others a rich sourej of abundant blessing approved unto God, a workman that needeth not be ashamed, rightly dividing 'The Word of Truth.”
We have pleasure in signing ourselves on behalf of subscribers and friends,
Reverend and Dear Sir, Years most sincerely,
Jame.^ Connfll, Vicar of Him men; mi th. William Smith Churchwarden. Edwajld Bird, John C. Swail, Joseph Crookes, Char les Andrews.

The sslver bore the following inscrip'ion : — ‘Tiv<» ntvl to the Rev. C. H. Buuchar, M.A., with a I’tir-M <>f Gold, by the Congregation of St. Paul A HniHiihTHnr.th, nnd other Friends in appreciation of In- earnest Christian Ministry, and a- a token of their deep |>er*ooal regard.
June, 1864

The Rev. Mr. Butcher, whose occasionally faltering voice betrayed tbe emotion be felt, replied in very grateful terms, concluding by expressing bis pain at parting with his friends at Hammersmith of whom he should alwayi think with tbe deepest regard

The fjw remaining friends with whom be parted 42 years ago wish him many years of peaceful happiness after his long and arduous service for the Master, and should opportunity offer would expend him a hearty welcome to the scene of bi; first curacy, somewhat altered since be left it, and we are sure this feeling will be sbared by every member of the con­gregation of the new St. Paul’s Church.
8. Martin
We do not hold ourMlree r«*J>on<lble for the opinion* ei proee*! by our corrojertidente, but wo wl«h, in n eplrtt of Uir pUy *11, penult—within certain tmomry UtnlU- free >li*c***iou.
THE PORT SAID AFFAIR
To the Editor of the "Egtptian Gazette

Sir,—I am sure that a a amber of your readers will agree with me that the police officer who had the misfjrtuoe of colliding with two pas •ODgeM in the Rae de Uoaameroe, Port Said, on Thursday last deserves great sympathy, and may we hope that the Gjvwrnment will eet be backward in acknowledging the gellant servicer of their worthy officer ami of the manner in which he performed his duty. Tbe promptitude of the whole businem is amasiag and worthy of note. Tbe steamre arrived at about 10 aea. and within two short hours one of the two gentlemen had not only comssitled tbe oSeeos but had beta triad before His Msjeety’a British Consul for drunkenness and aresok, and before 12 o'olook was ia the aative prison sarviag bio term ofotven days. One cannot help wonder ing how iaso short a time, withe prisoner, as, I anderetead under the iotlmoe of druk, the authorities ware able to satisfy themselves that they were dealing with a British subject. Bosh satisinotion it aaraui thiy did have, inMmunh aa the prisoner was dealt with by the Britirii Consul Gsureal.

However, Mr. Editor, without occupying more opsboe, may I suggrei khat it weold be no opportune moment to open a eebeeriptieo lirt for the porpoee of pereewtiap the eonsfobte with a memento of the event nnd aa it terms ho oams off wikb adsmsged tasbooebe, I haodly think we oould do bettor than let snob a prenentetiMK in tbe nhsenos of a Viotoria Crou, take the formof a new pines of hesdgosr. K others of the Britmh oommnnity will give their snpport I should he delighted to open the tot with a donation ot ten millisnaee. Thanking you for the space,—Yours, etc ,
A Bbitishir.
Port Said, 21st Deoember.
PIGEON SHOOTING AT HBLOUAN.
To the Editor of the “Barnau Gaikttb.”

Dear Sir,—1 am an occasional visitor to Helouan, and last Sunday I was sargsised to find that pigeon shootmg was being oasriod on daring the afternoon, very oloau to ous of the principal hotels, so alone, in feet, that one lady visitor informed me that a few days before, after n pigeon shooting match, five wounded birds had fluttered into het room through the open window. 1 will not experea my views as to the cruelty of this so sailed "sport ” of pigeon shooting. Most English people, I believe, have decided opinions on the sob jeot. I would merely suggest that if the hotdh in Helouan wish to lose their Britiab patien- ag", there is no easier way for them to tong this about than by allowing thio form- of sport to be carried on at little more than 100 yards distance from their visitors’ bed rooms—I sm, etc.,
Anglo Egyptian.

C. Aql’ILINA.
